Manuel Amago wrote:

>>[...] The smell is in the tension between the 
>>desired source code layout and the access rules of the 
>>language. I don't see how JUnit is responsible for this smell,
>>or a JUnit-based solution 
>>(like, say, hacking it to use reflection in order to break access 
>>control) that doesn't bring along serious code smells of its own.
>>
> 
> This problem is definitely not a JUnit problem.  It is just that it
> would be nice if JUnit could handle this problem (Works Out of The
> Box[1]).


It would be nice. I just don't see any way to do it without making JUnit 
tremendously stinky and ugly and dangerous. :(

Of course, if you take my position that wanting to test private methods 
from a separate package altogether is a bad smell, then it does Work Out 
of the Box. :}  It's doing *exactly* what i would want it to do - making 
me think about Why as well as How, and preventing shortcuts.


> Another tension is that of consistency: if you code ALL your test
> classes as Inner classes, you may well use them to test private access
> methods also.  If you don't, however, you add an extra smell and
> inconsistent use of Inner/Test classes.  This could become a maintenance
> problem.


I agree, whatever mechanism you use for associating test classes with 
the classes tested, it should be applied consistently. Personally, i 
write my test classes as same package, same directory. I don't find it 
clutters because i can exclude the test classes from jars via Ant, and i 
wind up with both the test class and the tested class in open editor 
sessions all the time anyway. (i would actually argue that the coupling 
between class heirarchy and source code file names in Java is a smell in 
itself, albiet a minor one. Certainly, this wouldn't be so much of an 
issue if we could just stick an inner class in a separate directory).

Taken this way, whether or not to unit test private methods becomes a 
conscious decision that should be made at the beginning of development. 
If you're going to test private methods from the start, then you should 
do all your test classes as inner classes (and accept the smell of large 
class files). If not, then you should treat the need to test a private 
method as a smell to be treated. I don't feel either is a terrible 
solution, although changing your mind in the middle of a project is painful.
